qas.question: Which sub class are most viviparous mammals in?
Viviparous mammals today are in which two main infraclasses?
What is present in all non-placental mammals?
What sub class are most placental eutherians in?
What class are placental eutherians in today?

plausible_answers.text: in the front of the mother's abdomen

qas.question: Where on the mother are the epipubic bones located?
What prevents a short gestation period in full pregnancy?
In marsupials what is a plesyomorphic condition shorter than?

context: Viviparous mammals are in the subclass <a0_0><b3_0>Theria<b3_0/><a0_0/>; those living today are in the <a1_0><b4_0>marsupial and placental<b4_0/><a1_0/> infraclasses. A marsupial has a short gestation period, typically shorter than <b7_0>its estrous cycle<b7_0/>, and gives birth to an undeveloped newborn that then undergoes further development; in many species, this takes place within a pouch-like sac, the marsupium, located <b5_0>in the front of the mother's abdomen<b5_0/>. This is the plesyomorphic condition among viviparous mammals; <b6_0>the presence of <a2_0>epipubic bones<b6_0/><a2_0/> in all non-placental mammals prevents the expansion of the torso needed for full pregnancy. Even non-placental eutherians probably reproduced this way.
